title: Nomad beefs up ChargeKey USB-C cable for keychains (and lowers price!)
description: The newly updated Nomad ChargeKey now puts 240 watts of charging power and fast data transfer speeds on your keychain. (via Cult of Mac - Apple news, rumors, reviews and how-tos)
author: David Snow
excerpt: The newly updated Nomad ChargeKey now puts 240 watts of charging power and fast data transfer speeds on your keychain.
text: News Now it can push up to 240 watts of charging power and transfer data at up toe 10Gbps. Photo: Nomad Nomad’s popular ChargeKey USB-C cable accessory, which can live on your keychain and help with gadget charging on the go, now handles up to 240 watts and delivers faster data transfer speeds, the company said Tuesday. So it can fast-charge all of your Apple gear, including MacBooks. This post contains affiliate links. Cult of Mac may earn a commission when you use our links to buy items. Nomad ChargeKey now boasts more power for quick charging and faster data transfer Connect on the go Nomad ChargeKey - USB-C | V2 Nomad's popular ChargeKey USB-C charging cable for keychains pushes up to a stout 240W of power and transfers data at up to 10GBps. Pros:Small, folding USB-C cable fits on keychainUp to 240W of fast-charging power-handlingUp to 10Gbps data-transfer speeds for large files like photos and videos The Nomad ChargeKey, first rolled out in 2013 and periodically updated, just got dramatically more powerful charging capabilities and enhanced data transfer speeds. And the new v2 version comes with a reduced price compared to its predecessor, saving folks about $10. The new USB-C to USB-C ChargeKey represents a major leap forward from its 2023 counterpart, boosting charging capacity from 60W to an impressive 240W. This substantial increase means the tiny cable can now effectively fast-charge everything from iPhones to MacBook Pro laptops at their maximum supported speeds. 10Gbps data transfer speeds with USB 3.1 Faster data transfer speeds will help with photo and video files.Photo: Nomad Beyond power delivery, the updated accessory addresses a key limitation of the previous model by upgrading from USB 2.0 to USB 3.1, enabling data transfer speeds of up to 10Gbps. This enhancement makes the accessory particularly valuable for users who need to quickly transfer large files or record camera footage directly to external drives while on the go. One particularly useful application for Apple users is the ability to charge AirPods directly from an iPhone while mobile, offering a convenient solution for emergency power needs. Despite its enhanced capabilities, the ChargeKey maintains its signature compact design that allows it to attach seamlessly to a keychain. The accessory features a durable braided nylon cable and electroplated zinc housings, with magnetic tips that secure together when not in use. The combination of ultra-portable design and high-speed charging makes it an ideal backup solution for Apple’s ecosystem of devices. Price: $25 Buy from: Nomad Connect on the go Nomad ChargeKey - USB-C | V2 Nomad's popular ChargeKey USB-C charging cable for keychains pushes up to a stout 240W of power and transfers data at up to 10GBps. Pros:Small, folding USB-C cable fits on keychainUp to 240W of fast-charging power-handlingUp to 10Gbps data-transfer speeds for large files like photos and videos
html:
• News

Nomad’s popular ChargeKey USB-C cable accessory, which can live on your keychain and help with gadget charging on the go, now handles up to 240 watts and delivers faster data transfer speeds, the company said Tuesday. So it can fast-charge all of your Apple gear, including MacBooks.

This post contains affiliate links. Cult of Mac may earn a commission when you use our links to buy items.

Nomad ChargeKey now boasts more power for quick charging and faster data transfer

Connect on the go

Nomad ChargeKey - USB-C | V2

Nomad's popular ChargeKey USB-C charging cable for keychains pushes up to a stout 240W of power and transfers data at up to 10GBps.

Pros:

  • Small, folding USB-C cable fits on keychain
  • Up to 240W of fast-charging power-handling
  • Up to 10Gbps data-transfer speeds for large files like photos and videos

The Nomad ChargeKey, first rolled out in 2013 and periodically updated, just got dramatically more powerful charging capabilities and enhanced data transfer speeds. And the new v2 version comes with a reduced price compared to its predecessor, saving folks about $10.

The new USB-C to USB-C ChargeKey represents a major leap forward from its 2023 counterpart, boosting charging capacity from 60W to an impressive 240W. This substantial increase means the tiny cable can now effectively fast-charge everything from iPhones to MacBook Pro laptops at their maximum supported speeds.

10Gbps data transfer speeds with USB 3.1

Beyond power delivery, the updated accessory addresses a key limitation of the previous model by upgrading from USB 2.0 to USB 3.1, enabling data transfer speeds of up to 10Gbps. This enhancement makes the accessory particularly valuable for users who need to quickly transfer large files or record camera footage directly to external drives while on the go.

One particularly useful application for Apple users is the ability to charge AirPods directly from an iPhone while mobile, offering a convenient solution for emergency power needs.

Despite its enhanced capabilities, the ChargeKey maintains its signature compact design that allows it to attach seamlessly to a keychain. The accessory features a durable braided nylon cable and electroplated zinc housings, with magnetic tips that secure together when not in use. The combination of ultra-portable design and high-speed charging makes it an ideal backup solution for Apple’s ecosystem of devices.

Price: $25

Buy from: Nomad

Nomad ChargeKey - USB-C | V2

Nomad's popular ChargeKey USB-C charging cable for keychains pushes up to a stout 240W of power and transfers data at up to 10GBps.

Pros:

  • Small, folding USB-C cable fits on keychain
  • Up to 240W of fast-charging power-handling
  • Up to 10Gbps data-transfer speeds for large files like photos and videos
